intro: Cyanococcus pensylvanicus, commonly known as the Pennsylvania bluecurls, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its striking blue or purple flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant has hairy, cylindrical stems and lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine pubescence. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland areas or along stream banks. Cyanococcus pensylvanicus is valued for its ornamental appeal and its role in supporting local pollinators.
